arts.ttl: The lowdown on Charlton Athletic 0 Reading 0 - Goalless draw doesn’t tell the full story
arts.sum: Charlton Athletic: Maynard-Brewer, Gillesphey, A Mitchell, Jones, Edwards, Small, Coventry, Berry, Docherty, T Campbell (Godden 88), Leaburn (Aneke 81). The visitors had a spell shortly after the restart – with Ashley Maynard-Brewer making a good save to deny Sam Smith – but once again it was Charlton who took over as they found plenty of joy playing through the Reading half.

arts.ttl: Nathan Jones asked about Lloyd Jones’ future - with in-form centre-back’s contract talks ‘ongoing’
arts.sum: Charlton Athletic boss Nathan Jones says that contract talks with centre-half Lloyd Jones are “ongoing.” We’re ongoing in terms of contract talks.

arts.ttl: Reading boss Hunt delighted with clean sheet at Charlton Athletic
arts.sum: “With the work the boys and us have put in over the last three or four weeks, and before that this season, they deserved that little bit of luck,” said Hunt, appointed as Reading’s new manager at the start of December. “We got that little bit of luck that we deserved and maybe we hadn’t had in the last two or three games, when we have had penalty shouts and stuff.

arts.ttl: Reading boss on Charlton Athletic stalemate and importance of away day clean sheet
arts.sum: Reading boss Noel Hunt felt his side had 'earned their luck' in a dogged 0-0 draw with Charlton Athletic. The Royals had to clear two efforts off the line and saw a Tyreece Campbell shot ruled out for offside at the Valley as both sides looked for a fourth successive win. Completing a period of 10 points from 12 over the festive period, the Royals earned their first away clean sheet since April in front of more than 2,600 travelling supporters. Speaking after the match, Hunt said: "With the work that we’ve put in over the last three or four weeks, and before, they deserve that little bit of luck that we maybe hadn’t had in the last three or four games. I thought the boys were amazing today." Most of the focus was on the backline, with Amadou Mbengue returning from illness to fill in at right-back and teenager Abraham Kanu starting at left-back. Tyler Bindon and Harlee Dean were imperious and managed to bail out goalkeeper Joel Pereira after the stopper uncharacteristically dropped a cross.

arts.ttl: Nathan Jones after goalless draw with Reading: We’re now showing that Charlton Athletic are one of the better sides in League One
arts.sum: There’s sides at the minute that are winning games, but when we play against these sides, it’s a really good football game. The home side had the lion’s share of chances to win the game but had to settle for a point.

arts.ttl: Charlton and Reading play out stalemate
arts.sum: Neither side could find the breakthrough.

arts.ttl: Dogged Reading end festive period unbeaten with goalless draw at Charlton Athletic
arts.sum: Two sides high on confidence after three straight wins, the opening stages flew by in what was a competitive half which lacked any real goalscoring chances. The Royals best chance came after 15 minutes as Abrefa’s cutback found Harvey Knibbs jogging on the spot in the penalty box, only for Lloyd Jones to dive in and block the shot before Ashley Maynard-Brewer was tested. As the half wore on, the Addicks grew stronger and half-chances came semi-regularly. Thierry Small fizzed a shot narrowly over the crossbar from 35 yards and shortly after he saw an attempt fly wide of the near post from a closer range. Despite the growing pressure, it took until nine minutes from the break for the first shot on target of the game. Harlee Dean lost possession and Tyreece Campbell was baring down on goal, but the forward could only fire down the throat of Joel Pereira.

arts.ttl: Reading team news: Chem Campbell among changes and misses return to Charlton Athletic
arts.sum: Reading winger Chem Campbell is likely to have played his final match for the club as he misses out on a return to former club Charlton Athletic. The Wolverhampton Wanderers youngster sees his loan expire on Monday having made 22 appearances and scored five goals. Missing out on a return to the Valley, a ground he called home for a spell last season, he is one of three changes made from the New Year's Day win at Cambridge United. Joel Pereira remains in goal, while a back four of Louie Holzman, Tyler Bindon, Harlee Dean and Abraham Kanu look to keep the Addicks at bay. The midfield trio remains unchanged, with Lewis Wing, Charlie Savage and Harvey Knibbs looking to keep up their fine form.

arts.ttl: Tickets sell out for Q&A session as iconic former Reading boss returns to the town
arts.sum: Tickets for an exclusive Q&A event with legendary Reading FC manager Steve Coppell at the Purple Turtle in April has sold out in a matter of weeks. Coppell guided Reading up into the Premier League in 2006 for the first time in the club's history as his side won the Championship with a record 106 points. The team went on to finish in eighth place in the Premier League the following season - missing out on a European place by a solitary point. The former Manchester United and England winger returns to Reading on Sunday April 27 for a Q&A event, which will see him reminisce about his time at the club. The Q&A starts at 5.30pm and will be followed by audience questions and a chance to meet the former Reading manager.

arts.ttl: Reading sell-out initial allocation for Charlton as thousands descend on capital
arts.sum: Over 2,500 Reading supporters are to be descending on London tomorrow as the initial allocation for Charlton Athletic sells out. Always a popular away day with its deep stand behind the goal, last year's 4-0 defeat at the Valley was the largest away turnout for the Royals last season (2,518). That feat looks set to be repeated this time around as the initial, advanced allocation of 2,510 officially sold out on Thursday. Another 600 tickets have been made available to Royals fans, which can be purchased from the ground at the gate, taking a total possible allocation to over 3,100. Reading last won at the Valley in 2016, a dramatic 4-3 victory for Brian McDermott's side with Deniss Rakels scoring a stoppage-time winner in front of the travelling supporters.
